trans-unit.source: Centre for Digital Humanities, Utrecht University

trans-unit.note: Currently selected slide number read by screen reader

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Learning outcomes analysis clarify and map your course goals

Click on one of the five levels to find examples of educational exercises or assignments that make use of generative AI to different degrees (levels 2-5) or not at all (level 1). You can check off examples that you are interested in. These will be included in your final report.
Next, pick one or more intended learning outcomes that are assessed in this way and whose assessment could be affected by the use of GenAI.
Generative AI - A three-step reflection tool

Welcome to the GenAI reflection tool. The aim of this tool is to stimulate reflection on the impact of generative AI on academic teaching. Students can use generative AI for almost all assignments. The question whether assessment forms need to be adapted as a consequence of this, depends on the intended learning outcomes that the assignments test. This is why this tool aims to make an explicit link between assessment forms and learning outcomes. Wherever the use of generative AI is considered problematic, the tool provides alternative assessment forms, or stimulates you to consider changing the learning outcomes.
In this step, you will receive information on how students can make use of GenAI for the assessment forms in your course.

After adding an assessment form, you decide whether the use of GenAI is a problem in this context, based on the ILOs that are tested. If you consider the use of GenAI in the assessment a problem, the tool suggests alternatives.
Known AI Uses for this assessment form
In this step, you will map the Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs) for your course and link each one to the most relevant Dublin Descriptor.
Please provide the name of your course. This will personalize the final report.
Does the use of GenAI in the assignment assessment affect the extent to which can be tested?
Select the options below that you would like to include in your summary report.
{VAR_PLURAL, plural, =1 {this learning goal} other {these learning goals}}
Step 3: Ideas for integrating generative AI in your course explore how generative AI can be used to enhance your course

Here, you are invited to reconsider exercises or assignments by involving generative AI to various extents. The AI assessment scale that this step is based on, has officially been accepted by the UU as a guiding principle. It helps teachers to think of generative AI in a less binary manner ‚Äì not as something that is either forbidden or approved, but as a set of tools that can be integrated in academic education to different degrees.
This tool consists of three subsequent steps:
No adjustments available. Select an assessment form first.
The Dublin Descriptors are internationally recognized criterias to classify learning outcomes, and used on a program-level in our department. They are organized into five categories:
Which ILOs are tested with this assessment? Select one or multiple.
Step 2: Assessment forms assess whether the use of generative AI in assignments negatively impacts the learning outcomes
For each ILO you enter, please select the Dublin Descriptor that best aligns.
Click the bars below to see examples of ways in which students may use GenAI for this assessment form.
Here you need to evaluate whether you can still test the ILO with the chosen assignment. Take into account that students can and may use GenAI.
No ILOs available. Add some in the previous step.
Enter the name of your course...
Additional information regarding the university policy on generative AI can be found here. (Links will open in a new tab.)
Below you will find a scale with five levels of AI integration in educational assessments, based on the AI Assessment Scale (AIAS) developed by Perkins et al. (2024).
(Link will open in a new tab.)
